floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are rising in response to recent heavy rainfall within the catchment. This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 1st October. The causeway at Earith has approximately 27 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 102cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 60 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 4pm today, Tuesday 1 October 2024.

This flood alert remains in force due to the combination of wave action and windblown spray on the coast tomorrow, Wednesday 02/10/2024. Flooding of low-lying land, promenades and roads is possible between 6:15am and 8:15am on Wednesday 02/10/2024. Areas most at risk include the the North Sea coast from Bridlington to Barmston particularly Bridlington South Pier and the Bridlington Lifeboat Station. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9am on Wednesday 02/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Heavy rain is currently falling in the Peterborough area which is causing the river levels to rise on the River Nene. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 01/10/24, or before if the situation changes.

Monday evening's tide at 23:15 on 30/09/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with strong Westerly Force 6 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.15 m. The total forecast tide is 5.48 metres Chart Datum (2.43 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Tuesday morning's tide at 11:30 on 01/10/2024 is forecast to be 36 cm higher (2.79 mAOD). Minimal flood impacts are possible Tuesday morningâ but wave heights and flood risk should reduce from Wednesday 02/10/2024. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 19:00 on 01/10/2024.

The Cuckmere River through Alfriston remains very high, but is now slowly falling. Through Tuesday, flooding will continue to affect fields, roads and gardens, including North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Cuckmere River through Hellingly has already fallen significantly. The Bull River through Hellingly remains higher than normal, with flood impacts likely affecting fields and roads. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible Tuesday afternoon, but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. Flood impacts in Hellingly should ease by Tuesday afternoon. In Alfriston, flood impacts could continue until Wednesday afternoon. However, another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Plan to avoid routes vulnerable to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 02/10/2024

The Powdermill Stream through Crowhurst has fallen significantly following Monday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads should continue to ease in Crowhurst through Tuesday (01/10/2024). No flood impacts are expected in Bulverhythe, where the Combe Haven will remain higher than normal until the weekend. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible on Tuesday afternoon (01/10/2024), but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. The river should continue to slowly fall, returning to normal in Crowhurst by Wednesday afternoon (02/10/2024). Another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept close by, and ready for installation, in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if property flooding is possible.

River levels are high but are now peaking on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Levels will being to drop later this afternoon but flooding is still possible through Monday and into Tuesday. Property flooding is not expected.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings as necessary. Drier conditions are expected from Tuesday onwards and the situation should improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 01/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels on the River Mole between Kinnersley Manor and Sidlow have peaked overnight and are falling steadily. However, river levels are continuing to rise steadily further downstream at Leatherhead and Cobham as a result of heavy rainfall overnight Sunday night, 29/09/2024 into Monday morning, 30/09/2024. Flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible from 9am today, Tuesday 01/10/2024, near the river, particularly between Leatherhead and Cobham. Flooding to property is not currently expected.
Further light rainfall is forecast today, Tuesday 01/10/2024 and we expect river levels to remain high between Leatherhead and Cobham until later this evening, 01/10/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to issue flood warnings if required.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and working with emergency services and partners in the area.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 7pm tonight, 01/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is still higher than normal near Barcombe, but is slowly falling, following Monday's rain. Small amounts of flood water could continue to affect roads, including Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and Barcombe Mills road. Minor flooding could also affect fields near the Anchor Inn and Barcombe Mills, but all impacts should ease by Tuesday afternoon 01/10/2024. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible on Tuesday afternoon, but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. River levels should fall, or remain low through to the end of the week. However, another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Some roads may continue to be affected by flooding, including Barcombe Mills road. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this message if new instances of property flooding is possible.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have peaked below the alert threshold, with no further rise forecast. No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and the Cadnam River at Cadnam is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 25mm of rain has been recorded in Romsey, this is a modest amount but follows 9 days of persistent wet weather, where more than a monthâs rain has been recorded. From 10:30 this morning (30/09/2024), the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the mill building at East Wellow. Rain clears eastwards by lunchtime and a dry afternoon follows. Tomorrow (Tuesday 01/10/2024) only a small amount of rain (10mm) is forecast. The rest of the week should remain relatively dry. The river will rise until at least 14:00 this afternoon (30/09/2024). As it peaks it will not cause property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 01/10/2024.

The River Adur is high, but slowly falling, following Monday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens, and roads at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury will continue to ease through Tuesday 01/10/2024. A small amount of rain (5mm) could be possible on Tuesday afternoon, but this should not cause river levels to rise significantly. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. The river should continue to fall, and is expected to return to normal from Wednesday afternoon (02/10/2024). Another area of low pressure is forecast this weekend, which could cause flood risk to return. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may continue to be affected by minor flooding on Tuesday (01/10/2024). Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if property flooding is possible.

The water level in the River Lymington at Brockenhurst is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, almost half a monthâs rain (29mm) has been recorded in Brockenhurst. From 14:00 today (Monday 30/09/2024) the river will be much higher than normal and drainage ditches through the New Forest will be flooding land and roads. It will be bank full as it flows through Martinâs Road and Balmer Lawn Road, and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 10 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. Rain has now cleared the area and a dry afternoon follows. Tomorrow (Tuesday 01/10/2024) only a small amount of rain (10mm) is forecast. The rest of the week should remain relatively dry. The river should peak around 15:00 this afternoon, remaining high until 16:00, before it will finally reduce. We continue to monitor the forecast and ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Watersplashes will deepen over the next 3 hours. Do not drive through floodwater. This message will be removed by 18:00 on Tuesday 01/10/2024.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising, following half a month's rain (30mm) on Monday morning. From 03:00 on 01/10/2024, flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and a small number of properties, including The Old Clergy House and properties near Willows Car Park on North Street. Flooding will be close to properties on River Lane and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Only isolated showers are forecast for the rest of the week. The river should begin to fall by 12:00 on 01/10/2024, and should return to normal by midday on Wednesday (02/10/2024). We believe river levels could rise a little higher than they were on Saturday. Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 16:00 on 01/10/2024.

items.description: Areas closest to Sankey Brook at Dallam
items.message:
High river levels are causing flooding overnight.
Flooding is expected to continue until 10:00 AM on 01/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Sankey Brook.
Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 01/10/2024, or as the situation changes.
